text: Bottle from The Beer Mongers, Portland. Aroma is bready malt, sweet ripe fruits, apricot, yeast, spicy notes, mild candied fruits, peach, touch of pear, lightly floral. Flavour is moderate to medium sweet and moderate bitter with a hint of tartness. Body is medium with fairly lively carbonation. Very nice complex array of farmhouse flavours, rich stuff.

Pours a warm honey gold with a medium white head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma is nothing special: bread, a little yeast and malt and a slight sweet straw. Mouthfeel is generally thin yet a slight touch of viscosity. Bubbles are small and subtle. Taste is light and a bit sweet. A little sourdough bread touched with a hint of honey-apple sweetness. Not to get too cute but it tastes like sunshine through water. As the label says, this is an easy beer to be enjoyed on a lazy sunny afternoon. Pairing perfectly with a little Mt. Tam from Cowgirl Creamery. 

I think its perfect for what its supposed to be. Im a fan.
Decent, slightly uininspired. Some sweet maltyness, a few esters, medium body. Slight touch of barn.

0.75l bottle. Clear dark orange body with a huge and lasting white head. Aroma of caramel, orange zest, sugar syrup, floral hops, sipces and apricot. Taste of caramel, apricot, floral hops, toast and some honey. Nice beer.

A dark yellow with orange notes, a head is medium and blond. Aroma has fruitness, flowers, some fruit candies and even perfume, hint of caramel. Tate has sweet fruitness, flowers, spicyness, some fruit candies and caramel body. Quite dry in the end due to spicyness and bitterness. Medium bodied, balanced and medium carbonation. Aromatic, complex and balanced. Even the big bottle keeps its interest.

750ml bottle shared @Pułapka, Gdańsk
Slight alcoholic aroma, spices, dusty room. A bit empty taste, bananas, spices, alcohol. Medium carbonation. Tiring.

Orange color, huge beige head. Sweet and floral aromas with yeast, citrus, peaches, straw, sugar and pineapple(?). Sweet taste of caramel, marmalade, raisins, peaches, slight alcohol, sugar and a light floral taste during the finish. Really well balanced!

750ml bottle from Systembolaget. Slightly hazy golden, dense white head, some lacing. Bread and malt aroma, yeast, toast and slightly fruity. Silky mouthfeel, medium carbonated, medium to full bodied. Fruity and malty taste, red apples, pears, biscuits, bread, notes of alcohol, hay, minerals and earthy. Crisp and warming finish.

750 mL bottle. Originally reviewed 3/23/2014.

Pale orange. Nice white head. Thick white collar.

Smells of pale malt. Some belgian sweetness. Fruity esters. A little peppery.

Tastes of pale malt balanced by white pepper and wine-like fruitiness. Bitter grassy finish.

Medium body. Almost too heavy. Well carbonated. 

Straightforward, but tasty.
Lightly hazybgolden with a white head. Floral, honey, light spice, some hay, light bread malt. Medium fizzy body. Spicy bite in the finish. Enjoyable.

Amber with a good pale head. Aroma is caramel, spice, hint of honey and dried stone fruits. Light bodied, starts lightly malty on the palate but finishes lightly dry and earthy. Taste is caramel, Belgian spice, earthy grain. Nice.
Very dull I think Im not fan of the style. Nothing much I can say about it, honey is noticeable and weird not nice bitterness

Tap at Stone - clear golden color with small white head. Taste is lemon, yeast, spices, medium bitter dry finish. This is my first Bière de Garde, I think I highly like this style. Would be interesting to know why this should be for women though :)
UPDATED: DEC 10, 2016 Fresh from the tap at Stone Berlin. Copper-golden with a stable with foam head. Very good and very nice for women.

Bottle shared. Poured a murky amber with a frothy white head. The aroma is toffee caramel, sweet malt, yeast, alcohol. The flavour is moderate sweet with a rich smooth crisp, sweet malty, fruity alcohol, dry yeast palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

A 1 pint 9.4 fl oz bottle, bottled sometime in 2015 (as far as I can tell), and poured into a dAchouffe tulip glass. It poured a clear copper colour with a big two finger off white head that dissipated fairly quickly but left decent lacing. Aromas were generally light, sweet malt, toasty bread, orange zest, apple, pear, earthy and spice. Tastes biscuity, light berries and caramel with a touch of honey, peppery spice and light alcohol. Dry, medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Overall, this was nice, enjoyable and easy to drink.

Aroma:

Medium aroma of malts, caramel, yeast, wood, fruit and bread.

Appearance:

Turbid/opaque golden/amber beer with a slight/medium off-white head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts medium sweet with malts, caramel, yeast, wood and fruit; ends slightly dry with bread.

Overall:

This beer is rather intense, complex and balanced. Extremely good for how not intense it actually is. Probably lost a lot of hop flavours, but the aging adds a really rustic feeling to this beet at the same time.
Bottle shared by steveoj hazy pale yellow with a lively white head. Classic farmhouse aromas and flavors. Quite dry and a bit tart.

750ml bottle from Green Mountain Liquor.. Pours out a milky pale golden with soft white bubbly head. Spicy aroma, equal parts floral and savory. Taste follows, spice, yeast, bready malts and faint floral notes.

750ml bottle thanks to stevoj. Pours out a peach color topped with a white head. Nose is spice light floral perfume notes and some spice. Taste is more of the spice malts light floral perfume and some grain.

Sample at SBWF 2016. 

Hazy golden/orange with a white head. Aroma of fruit, light spices and yeast. Similar taste. The body was medium and the finish on the dry side.

Citrus and spicy aroma, hazy yellow straw color, light tan foam. Mango and apricot flavor with carbonated mouthfeel. Hint of floral undertone in flavor, crisp and feels light for 7% abv

750 mL bottle from Ridgewood Wine & Beer, Raleigh. Dark orange pour with a foamy off-white head. Aroma of lemon peel, faint leather, and light Belgian-style yeast. Taste features a subtle tartness with notes of white pepper, cardamom, and light horse blanket. Moderately dry finish. This one is a bit difficult for me to pinpoint all of the flavors but the important thing is I like it.

7%ABV. Bière de garde.

Poured out amber gold. 10ºSRM.

Nose is candy, like a jolly rancher, maybe mentos fruit, juicy fruit gum. Light formaldehyde aroma.

Mouthfeel is light syrup. Palate has sweet roasted malty with honey, red dates, Cheng tng (which is a local dessert of rock sugar, white fungus, red dates) this description thanks to my friend, Keola. Hops are noble in nature with solid bitter, which is barely there, so for me this is still malt balanced. Some spice and pepper in the finish which might be hops are rye.

Finish is clean, light sugary and so very very very much like Cheng Tng which is a light sweet candy like palate.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2016 Older bottle bought online. Loose, milky, snow white, moussy head over an equally cloudy peach blonde beer with salmon pinkish hue. Aroma of ripe peach, banana peel, iron, red apple, old cookies, honey, canned pineapple, pear, white raspberry and a hint of onsetting rusty oxidation. Fruit sweet onset, very appleish, hints of peach, dried banana and dried apricot, softish carbo, honeyish, slick malt sweetness in the middle with a metallic zing to it somewhere, tad bready too, leading to a somewhat thin finish with only softly bittering, herbal, tea-like hops which do leave a slight peppery flavor after swallowing, but it is the overall apple-like sweetness which prevails, along with that obnoxious hint at oxidation. Clearly a "bière de garde" should be able to last longer than a few years in a cellar without oxidizing this much, but apart from that, this is, to me at least, not better than the classic northern French examples of the style. It has a certain straightforwardness and a Belgian yeast quality not unlike e.g. its La Choulette or Chti counterparts, but it feels too soft and sweet for the style, with too much yeastiness going on. Not entirely true to style and certainly one of the least interesting Lost Abbey beers for me.
Draft at the source on 6/29/2016. Hazy gold, white head. Aroma of bready malt. Taste is bread, malt, mild fruitness, and spice. Decent for the style.

A corked 0.75l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. Looks really nice with a deep orange cloudy looking body under a medium sized really nicely lacing off-white head. The nose has some soft yeasty and sweet fruity things going on. Soft caramelized apples with candied sugar and something mild both dusty and spicy. Smells nice. It has a good thick and oily feeling in the mouth and its above average on the almost creamy bubbles. Like the taste. Sweet green fruity apples, some Belgian yeast, a little bit of white sugar and alcohol is also present. In a way its softly oxidized. Not much bitterness. Mmmhh.. Quite a nice one again from those Californian magicians. 19.02.2014

It pours golden with a full head. It is hazy with a slightly off white head. It has a malty sweet aroma highlighted by toast and bread. There are some spices and light fruit as it warms. It has flavors of toast and bread. There are also moderate spices and low pepper. As it warms, it has a fruity ester character that develops. It has a dry finish with a moderate body. There is some alcohol warming. Overall, this is a beer balance toward the malt with a complex blend of flavors.

Pint poured at waypoint public house in San Diego. Pours copper with white head and good lacing. Server described their beers as having "funky"
Flavors and it was a good deScriptor. Little smell other than yeast. Taste was smooth with a peppery finish. Little carbonation. While its good, I dont love it but I suspect its a style thing rather than a flavor thing.

Aroma of malts and hops. The malt is on the sweet and metallic side, the hops are floral, blond. Lovely golden, hazy. Sparkling. Excellent head, frothy. Bittersweet taste. Not much of anything. Seems thin on the palate, bitter finish which I quite like. Not a bad beer, nor is it a great beer.

0.75 bottle. Clear, dark orange color and a large, off-white head of good retention leaving notable lacing. The aroma is malty, mostly caramel with a touch of hops and an unfortunate hint of metal. The taste is sweet, mostly fruity with grains, malts, and flowers all adding to the composition. A medium body, a somewhat creamy texture, and a soft carbonation. Finish is long, gets slowly bitterer with time and strikes everything just a tiny bit off-balance. Overall this is certainly a good beer, hard to find much to complain, though it is not exactly praiseworthy either.

Yellow color with foam layer. Light alcoholic and yeasty nose with hints of fruits. Milky mouth feeling with a sweet and alcoholic taste. Strong and mild at the same time. Calm and light alcoholic aftertaste.

Bottle. Some apples, some grapes, but rather low in aroma. Some farmhouse. Very round and balanced, but not much of anything. Im a bit torn about this, as it is easy to drink but rather mellow at the same time.
Aroma of bread and a hint of spice, pours a copper color with a short lasting white head. A slightly sweet taste with notes of bread and raisins with an oily feel and a decidedly bitter finish.

Taste is light iron, sugar, caramel, candy, sugar, dough, some dull BE qualities, lemon & caramel. Substantial body with some light iron. Rather dull but decent.

Draft at the Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey Brewery. Poured a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Aroma was a nice dusty lemon notes, grassy notes. Nice spice fruit notes. Tasty.
backlog, bottle. Orange looks, lively white head. Aroma is yesty, zesty. Mouthfeel is dry, esters are overpowering.
On tap at the brewery. Orange color with small white head. Aroma is a bit fruity, a little bit funky. Taste is jam, fruity, red apples, not tart, but dry finish. Not a bad Biere de garde.
Orange and tangy taste. White head. Draft pour at Lost Abby /port brewing. Fruits and Carmel. Not bad

Sweet apricot aroma. Pours murky orange with a decent sized white head. Flavor is all sweetness with hardly any hop bitterness detected.

Przyjemne piwo, ale awangardy bym się tam nie doszukiwał. Warte spróbowania, ale niekoniecznie w tej cenie. Smakuje trochę jak spropsowany i doprawiony ziołowo lager wyższej klasy. Fajne piwo, ale bez przesady.

Love it. Pours a hazy copper colour with a thick, dense light beige head. There is a steady stream of carbonation in the body and no lacing. The aroma is lightly spiced, bready, caramel, a bit spicy and floral with a nice ripe fruit note. Rich without being heavy or cloying. A nice bready profile, a bit musty and earthy with light esters, a pinch of coriander spice, orange peel and crisp apples. Toasted malts are balanced well with light spice and floral hop accents. A beautiful brew overall.
Caramel and some Belgian yeast. Some candy sugar with some balanced Belgian character. Finished with nice mellow fruits. Well balanced brew within all these flavors.

75cl bottle shared in a chalice. Light orangey colour with a voluminous white head which lasts well. Aroma is spiciness, Belgian yeast and stone fruits. Taste is perfectly balanced and very moreish. In addition to the usual spiciness a definite hint of orange is present which makes this bittersweet and spiciness with a slight earthiness. Very impressive effort and very flavoursome example of the style.
Well done for style. Pours hazy orange with great head and lacing. Light tangy finish. Soft carbonation. Citrus and fermented fruit. Good stuff. Bottle.

Bottled 750ml. -at Svijet Piva Zagreb. Cloudy orange/golden coloured, medium sized off-white head, whiff of malt in the nose. Sweet malty, light fruity hoppy, notes of caramel and yeast...and thats it. Mild, mild spicy presence. Expected better for sure.

[2/22/15] Draught at Port Brewing/Lost Abbey in San Marcos. Clear golden. Fruity and spicy aroma. Sweetish flavor, fruity and spicy. Medium-bodied.

I'd saved this bottle about three years, and was concerned about how well it had held up. Shouldn't have been! Rich and fruity. Hazy gold. Improving greatly as it warms up from the too cold refrigerator. I love it and want more.

75cl bottle shared at Biervana, danke. Full golden amber pour. Redolent of wild honey, bakers malt enlivened by orchard fruit peel. Pleasant execution of a broad, potentially heavy-handed style.
Bottle @ unibaren. With Maxi, mads, Palle, lillebror. Hazy orange, medium white head, some lacing. Fruity, orange, peach, little sour, malty. A bit tart. Medium carbonation. Dry mouth feel.

On tap at the brewery in San Marcos.

Bottle 750ml. [2012]
Pours clear golden with low beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is of malt, sugar, candi, some flowers, belgian yeast, slight caramel. Taste is of malt, faint bitterness, fruits, cream, belgian yeast. Palate: Medium body. Medium carbonation. Overall: Good Bière de Garde. Nothing mind blowing, but well done.

Bottle (750 ml). Bottled in 2012. Shared by Sam, thanks! Clear golden with a small ring of white foam and little lacing. Aroma is of raisin bun, grape must, light spiciness, grassy notes and malt. Taste is also of grape must along light spiciness, breadied malt and grass. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Well executed. This beer is within the style, but manage to be just enough different than a typical Bière de Garde to stand out of the group (not necessarely being better though). A tad bland, but drinkable.

On tap at Barrels & Bottles. Golden, hazy appearance with a lacy white head. Aroma of bready malts, earthy yeast, light spices, floral notes and herbs. Similar flavor, crisp, smooth and creamy with a medium body.
Another good beer from lostabbey. Blond white foam. Grains, cereals, hops, yeast. Balanced.ok!

Nice beer. Bottle from Whole Foods Pasadena. Pours clear golden lots of head and lots of lacing. Nose is apple, cereal. NOtes of apple, cheerios, light sweet and some yeast. Taste was light bitter, light sweet. Fully body with lively carbonation.
Tap in SF, pours hazy orange, white head, lacing, smell is caramel, fruity, citrus, taste is bitter, smooth, medium body, awesome.

Bottle shared with daje at Cafe Sara
Deep copper, frothy white head. Smell of dark fruits, faint hops and caramel. Moderate sweet, quite fruity, dark fruits and malts, quite nice malt base; dry mouthfeel. Moderate bitter, some hops in the finish. Very nice BdG; quite true to style but nire fruity and hoppy than alot of the french interpretions. Good stuff

Bottle. Pours cloudy golden with a medium off-white head. Aroma is sweet with grain, apple, caramel, hay, honey, rye and spice. Taste is light+ sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is moderate. Finishes dry and spiced.

Bottle at Cafe Sara, February 11th 2014. Clear orange body with a frothy white head. Aroma starts with apples, oranges, caramel, with spicy yeast showing as the beer warms. Sweet fruity taste with raspberries, oranges, slightly tart, wheat. Nice spicy bitter finish.
On draft at the brewery. Pours a cloudy good with an off white head. Light malty nose. Flavors of tropical fruit. Crisp tart finish.

Bottle. Very cloudy with a good head. Nice aroma and is decent going down. The taste was a big let down. Everything stared well, but by the time I looked for the taste, there was little to be found. May compliment good, but unforgettable on its own.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle poured. Light golden and copper appearance with a small head. Subtle citrus aroma. The beer is smooth on the tongue but it lingers and not necessarily in a good way.
Pretty good farmhouse ale. I remember grass and yeast notes. Fairly light and drinkable. Didnt stand out too much, a little forgettable.
Bottle. Cloudy yellow pour with a white head. Straw and grass aromas. Grass and yeast highlights with wood and mild spice lowlights. Good body and mouthfeel. Solid..
One of my favorite styles, I like to think of it as saison light. For the style, this is a superb example. Hint of Belgian yeast. Nice carbonation. Perfectly flavored.

Big Brew Bachelorette party. Sweet banana aroma, prickly champagne bubbles, good chick brew with a decent alcohol flavor. Sounds wierd but with a fresh orange in it, the ladys are getting chill. Nit your daddys Coors light. Something all could enjoy.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 19.02.2014, 0,75l bottle sampled @ BBGTC tasting:
Big creamy longlasting head. Aroma is slightly concentrated fruity, dried fruits, citrus, toffee, almond cake, butterscotch, honey, yeast. Taste is slightly yeasty, light malts, yeast, dried fruits, honey, heather, hay, weeds, hints of almond essence. Medium bitterness, slightly dry mouthfeel. Nice.

Pours a near-clear orange with a large, fluffy head. Aroma is rich fruity with light citrus notes and a lightly oxidised sweetish note. Taste is sweet but balanced. Fruity with berries and light caramel notes. Awesomness embottled! Lost Abbey proves again that they are indeed one of the best breweries out there.

Bottle @ BeerTemple, Amsterdam.
Fruity nose, little wet dog.
Orange yellow pour, with thick white head, but it quickly fades.
Fairly floral, ripe fruits (pear, peach). Malt bitter finish. Well balanced, but tad on the sweet side.

750ml bottle. Clear golden color. Tiny size, white head, stays as a ring. Just pure malts in aroma. Weak aroma. Sour, citrus, candy, esters in taste. Something in this flavor is disturbing, but I cannot tell what exactly.

Nice floral lemony great aroma. Very subtle. One of the best farm ales Ive. Ever had. Perfect nice head. Nice carbonation fruity very amazing. Sat for one year prior to drinking. Awesome! But not to be had with food. Great porch rocker.
Aroma of the summer meadow field (?boli??). Taste is fruity, malty, a bit on the sour side. There are better brews definitely.

Bottle pour (Līgo Ziema 2014, Riga)
Pale amber, tight head settles to a ring. Nettly bretty aroma. Bland in the mouth, watery. Adequate as a beer, seems to have been made with the usual beer ingredients, probably with a brett cube thrown in. Covers 7% well, but thats the best thing I can say about it.

750ml Flasche. Trübes orangegelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone.
Geruch nach Malz, Karamell, fruchtig, leicht herb.
Geschmack malzig süß, fruchtig, leicht herb werdend und trocken zum Abgang.

Had a meal with bread that was made with this beer and have to say: it was the best tasting homemade bread Ive had. So naturally, I had to try a bottle. I was very pleasantly surprised with the smoothness and exceptional flavor of this brew. It has mild hints of a doughy bread, citrus, and is slightly sweet. Ive only tried approximately 20 different flavors so far, but this one is very near the top.
22 oz bottle pours a hazy golden color with a nice white head. Aromas of bread, yeast, biscuit. Light bodied, simple and refreshing.

Growler from tap at Central Liquors. Pours slightly cloudy golden, plenty of carbonation. Not-quite-citrus vegetal aroma, hints of bread and biscuit in the malt profile. Not a hoppy beer, not a malty beer, overall an enjoyable ale with a crisp finish, great with food as described. Perhaps a great way to get the Miller, Coors or Bud drinker to make the switch to "something more."
Tasty Belgium-style beer on decent bar menu at Matchsticks restaurant Palm Springs.

Pour out of bottle, hazy yellow pour with white head, aroma brought notes of yeast, white fruit, hints of earthy yeast as well some funky tones, touch of grain, grass in there, hints of spice, caramel. Taste is a mix of biscuit, some bready dough, touch of yeast, earth, slight lemon, and fruity notes, finishing bitter, dry.

[ASPETTO] 			
aranciato chiaro, leggermente velata, abbondante schiuma color crema, cremosa , buona persistenza

profumi erbali, fieno, con note di frutta gialla, cereali,

Bottle at Nikos, with friends. Pour is slightly hazy orange with a big white head and great lacing. Bready, cereal, caramelly, fruity, tangy, grassy, and doughy aroma. Taste is fruity, straw, cracker, light pepper, bready, doughy, and grassy with a dry finish. Medium mouthfeel with high carbonation. Tasty - just not my favorite style.

Bottle shared at Beer Temple. Pours cloudy golden with a ring off white head. Aroma of yeast, citrus, malt, caramel and fruit. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Bottle sampled. Pours cloudy golden. Aroma is spicy, herbal, malty, some bubblegum and pineapple. Taste is quite sweet and light bitter. Full bodied with average carbonation.

Glass at bier temple courtesy of and shared with sic1314.
Thin white head. Very hazy golden blond pour. Nice brew.
Poured dark medium orange with a small off white head. Aroma of light spicy berries. Medium body, flavour of moderate citrus, light malt. Short fruity end.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2013 What a wonderful brew. This hits on every angle. A true European styled bier de mars. I can think of a thousand things to eat alongside this elegant craft. Cheese, grilled veggies, charcuterie... Hot dogs. Thank you Lost Abbey!

Taster at brewery. Pours golden with a white head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. A bit of yeast on the nose. Kind of fruity on the tongue. Has a bit of hop bite on the tongue. Im not sure I get the baking bread vibe but its solid.
Draft at Black Powder Tavern. Pour a hazy orange with medium off-white head and nice webbed lace. Nose of caramel, fruit  citrus, dried, tropical, bread. Medium body, slightly hot, mild bitterness.

On draft at Pizzacato in San Diego. Pours deep golden, clear, with a big creamy white head. Hay aroma, some yeast, with light pale malt sweetness. Flavor is very light hay and hops, again with light malt honey sweetness. Does not finish particularly clean or crisp, and there is lingering yeast on the palate. relatively light bodied with medium carbonation. This tasted much like a standard Helles lager to me when I was expecting a bit more farmhouse and light yeasty goodness. Only OK in my book.

75cl bottle. Hazy golden with small head. Aroma is yeast, esters, bisquit. Taste is some more esters and banana, yeast funk and malty sweetness. An ok beer but rather prefer a Belgian style saison. To mutch hitting the sweet spot for me.
Fra flaske på Cardinaltreff okt-13: syrlig og frisk med litt sødme og en god dose biterhet og urter i siste sving.
Slightly sweet, orangy taste. Aroma as expected from a bier du garde. Easily drinkable, although a bit on the sweet side.

750ml bottle. Clear orangey golden colour with huge, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Fruity aroma has notes of raspberry, a sweet biscuit and caramel touch, somewhat herbal overtones. Taste is dry, minimally tart, hints of raspberry, straw, unspecific minimally sweet, grainy, bready, biscuity malt basis. Neither fish nor fowl.
Cloudy golden colour with a white head. Slightly sour aroma with orange, apricot, caramel, a medicinal note. Sticky, full body. Sweet and yeasty flavour with candy sugar, lots of fruits, wheat.
Hazy orange pour with light white head. Aroma is fruity. Lots of citrus. Taste is sweet with a little bitter. Fairly carbonated. Enjoyable.

Bottled on 9/1/12 consumed on 9/11/13. Lets see how well it garded. Hazy orange pour big frothy head. Smells like apple cider vinegar/lemony, german hops, yeast. Tastes like a musty yeasty bland brown ale. Brettanomyces comes in here and blankets. Maybe too much secondary ferment. At least its balanced. So balanced its boring.

Pours light amber color, balanced, malty, fruity, but not as earthy as a great biere de garde should be. Biere de Garde in French means "beer that has been kept guarded." This version neednt be guarded, but is very sessionable.

75 cl bottle @ romanttinen ulkoilmamaistelu, bottled 14.09.2012
Aroma is musty and malty with some grassy hops, grain and apricot. Flavour is sweetish with apricot, some grainy malt, grassy hops and hints of spices. Dryish finish. Alcohol is clearly present and perhaps even disturbs a little. Bière de Garde is not my favourite style, but this is unusual and good. Gift of the Magi was American Bière de Garde, this is a German one.

75 cl bottle. Bottled on 14.09.2012.
Pours clear golden color with a large frothy head. Aroma of grass, faint hops, pale malts and some herbal and spicy notes. Flavour of malts, some caramel, hay, faint spice notes and some dried fruits. Quite thin and a bit dry at the end. Too malty for me.
2323

Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle corked and capped poured into a tulip. Pours hazy golden with medium white head. Dry floral aroma, medium body, well carbonation, and nice lacing. Taste is floral and dry finish.

750 ml bottle. Translucent copper with a fluffy white head of foam. Decent retention. Aroma is sweet and a little eatery with clove and nutmeg. Tastes yeasty and sweet. Some alcohol warmth in the finish.
Hazy golden appearance, nice thick white head. Aroma is mostly yeast, some sourdough. Taste is mild, yeasty and more bread and barnyard funk, sour finish. Just okay, I was hoping from more.

Bottle. Pours dark golden with sediments and a finger thick creamy head. Aroma is sweet malts with toffee, honey and flowery meadows, as well as a dark funkiness with yeast and notes of wood. Full body with an average to lively carbonation. Flavour is quite tart with yeast and malts with grain and wood, as well as notes of tobacco, vanilla, prunes and dark fruits, with a long astringent finish.

Expected a little more out of this one. Although, it is a very enjoyable brew with plenty of saison character and just a hint of funk. Just wish the funkiness had been showcased a bit more. O well...mountain lions are the biggest cats that purr...
October 2012. Bottle. Cloudy dark yellow with a white head. Malt, hops, spice, yeast, grass and floral notes. Plenty of hops to give a dry finish. Very refreshing.

2013.06.21, bottle bought at Birofilia festival in Poland. Pours light orange, somewhat hazy, with nice, although not too stable, white head. Aroma is hop forward, with prominent citrusy and grassy notes. Same notes dominate the flavor, together with yeasty character reminiscent of belgian ales. Toasty, malty character is present, but not very pronounced. Pleasantly dry aftertaste. Overall, a very enjoyable and well balanced beer, although I would expect more malty character from a biere de garde.

750ml bottle, thanks to DanielCoor for sharing. Hazy golden orange color. Thin white head, some decent lace. Smooth, lighter crisp carbonation. Bigger body. Light, toasty, lightly wheaty, light spicy aroma. Light zesty, light citrusy taste. Light sweet. Alright biere de garde

Bottle shared thanks to Tim and Rachel! Pours a hazy golden orange with fluffy white head that disappeared to thin cap. Aroma of light yeast, grainy malt, slight citrus, all faint, so not too positive. Taste is kind of like a pseudo Belgian IPA, slightly earthy. Not sure how I feel about it, balanced and easy to drink, nothing crazy though.
Tasty ale. However it wasnt outstanding. Nothing stood out. I paired with a pulled pork maybe the pairing hindered me ale

750 ml bottle to snifter (thanks DanielCoor). Looks good; a hazy orange with white lacing. Smells solid; sweatband yeasty with some citrus. Tastes like it smells, only blander, and without the citrus. Average on the palate. Decent, but nothing special.
Bottle.  Lactic lemon malt aroma.  Hazy golden yellow with small head.   Lightly sour milk, lemon peel, and light malt flavor.  Light bitter finish.
750ml bottle pours a hazy yellow orange with frothy white head. Big yeast aroma. Apple orange and wheat taste. Great beer

Bottle corked and caged shared by Ryan, thanks for sharing, poured a light cloudy orangish color with aromas of light lemon, hay, some dill and a touch of light funk.  Flavors were the same, light mustiness in the aftertaste, a solid beer.

Bottle courtesy of StefanSD.  Clean juicy lemony-orange-pineapple and light yeasty aroma.  Cloudy straw gold with a large white head, moderate lacing. Lightly sweet citrus, bready malt, and spice flavor with a hint of a grassy bitter finish. Light crisp body, moderate carbonation. Very refreshing, highly sessionable.
Poured from the tap. Clear copper colour with minimal white head. Orange and cinnamon aroma. Light watery taste of same aroma. Lacks finish.

7/IV/13 - 75cl bottle from Geers (Oostakker) @ Erwins place - bottled: IX/14/12 (2013-311) Thanks to Erwin for sharing the bottle! 
Clear orange beer, big irregular creamy off-white head, pretty stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: hay, grassy, bit lemony, honey. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: bit sweet, malty, orange peel, spicy touch, soft bitterness. Aftertaste: fruity, little bitter, orange peel, some honey.
Nice unassuming beer.  It doesnt taste strongly of anything, but the overall effect is pleasing.
Small white head on top of hazy orange.  Aroma of musty bakery with a floral overtone.  This beer needs more carbonation and a bit more hops to set out apart from other farmhouse ales.

Slight haze, golden with white fluffy head.  Hint of mustiness in the nose.  Crisp bite from the carbonation and hops, slightly creamy palate, grassy flavor.  Well balanced, between the spice of the hops and the malt.  Will be a welcome beverage on a summer day.
Pours hazy golden with white fluffy head. Aroma of grass, pineapple and barnyard. Taste with grassy and earthy notes. The finish is dry of grass and a metallic feeling. Refreshing

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2013 Pours light cloudy yellow to golden with huge white head making super nice lasing (different although from Vells glass whom we shared bottle). Aroma - dominant pineapply, vinegar, sweetish malty, a bit sour. Later it comes a bit farmhouse. Mouthfeel is above medium bodied, light dry finish, in aftertaste comes some herbal notes of hopping, mild sweet from malt. Taste- malty sweet, but not sugary, pleasant, mild hopping bitter; light spicy on tongue. For 7% alcohol is not notable at all (only after), flavor @ later stages becomes more malty and aroma hopped, mild bitter, lively but not high carbonated. Overall - very nice ale, far away parallels with barley wine and pale lager at the same time.
update: remembering that foam performance was one of the best.

Cloudy golden with huge white head. Quite stable. Awesomly lacing.
Aroma.. fruity pineapple, sweetish interesting maltiness with quite hoppy finish, grassy.
From not pushing sweetness to kinda sourness and bit bitter finish. Nicely balanced and quite complex. Not noticed ABV at all.
Nice exp.. refreshing and interesting beer
Orange pour with off white head, nice and big. Sweet malt, with a touch of fruit, spice and hops in the nose. Tastes sweet with malt and fruit in the front and a bitter/alcohol finish.

On tap 4 oz. pour at the Lost Abbey tasting room in San Marcos, CA.

Clear, bright straw with off-white head and excellent lacing.

Aroma of mild citrus, yeast, peach, caramel, wet leaves and light floral hops.

Taste of caramel, fruit (apple, pear, citrus and peach), yeast, bread and floral hops.

Medium body and medium carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Golden color. Tastes fruity and earthy. Very drinkable. One of my favorites.  Like most of Lost Abbey's beers, this does not disappoint. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Fruit and grassy hops in the aroma.  Flavor is sweet with fruit, spice.  Aftertaste has spice but some unpleasant metallic flavor.  Overall this is OK but not great.

Bottle at home (Beermerchants.com) 05/01/13.
Hazed golden with a good sized white head.
Nose carries caramel, light soap, yeast esters, lemon, spice.
Taste comprises yeast esters, caramel, some hop presence, lemon curd, candied sugars, grassy notes, little earthy/rustic feel, touch of soap.
Medium bodied with fine carbonation leading to a bitter sweet dry finish.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: I had heard many good things about this beer... but I was somewhat disappointed by this. There was absolutely nothing bad about it, and I could tell that all the ingredients were of the highest quality, but the taste was simply too mild to keep my interest. The aftertaste and very nicely sparkling palate grew after several sips, but the flavour never developed for me. It had a very nice flavour, but I could not even discern the strongest of the flavours of this beer until I had drank nearly half of a 750ml bottle... The flavour is complex and wild, I wanted to like it (based on how much I love Orval and Dupont,) but it was simply too mild to impress me.
Pain grillé, houblons épicés et floraux, esters de levure bien incorporés. La buvabilité est évidente. Pas mon genre de bière en général mais celle-là va se terminer facilement.

750 mL bottle from Sun Devil Liquors in Phoenix AZ, served in a tulip. Pours hazy caramel with a moderate tan head that remains and laces well. 
The nose is grainy, with lots of caramel, herbs, earth and a touch of piney hops. The flavour is quite sweet throughout with lots of caramel and a touch of honey. Delicate piney hops provide balance without overpowering. Earthy and barnyardy notes enhance the complexity. The finish is long, sweet, malty and barnyardy. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and average carbonation. Overall, this is a great bière de garde. Sweet, subtle and sophisticated, it is a very nice ale for sitting out on the patio with friends. Kudos to the brewers at Lost Abbey! 2012-03-11
Pours orange with an off white head and spicy, fruity aroma. Taste is similar, of fruits, spices, and yeast with a long, fruity finish while slightly bitter.

Pours a golden hazy rusty color with a magnificent head. Nose is yeasty, fruity, and spicy. Taste is a mildly sour and fruity with a mouthful of yeast. Finish is fruity and yeasty as well, with a taste of alcohol. Quaff Score 7 / 10

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating.  Pours hazy golden orange color with a nice 3 finger fluffy white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Nice foamy lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of big apple, pear, pepper, orange peel, caramel, bread, floral, grass, coriander, earth, honey, light funk, and herbal.  Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity.  Taste of pear, apple, pepper, citrus peel, coriander, bread, caramel, clove, honey, floral, grass, earth, and herbal spiciness.  Lingering notes of light fruits, citrus, pepper, bread, coriander, clove, caramel, floral, grass, honey, and herbal spiciness on the finish for a good bit.  Great balance and complexity of flavors; with a very nice malt and yeast spiciness balance; with zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and lightly prickly mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent Biere de Garde style.  Very nice flavor complexity and balance; very smooth and crisp to sip on.  Really enjoyed this one.

This pours a cloudy copper color with bubbles constantly rising to the top for a thick white head. The aroma has a yeasty, banana, farmhouse ale scent. The initial flavors are wheat mixed with citrus that create a well balanced flavor with the yeast. The texture is superb while being light tasting to the tongue with a dry finish.

6 dec 2012, tap. Light gold, clear, no bubbles. Nose is soft apple juice and slight tart saison yeast. Thin body and moderately fizzy. Reminds me of a sharp lager. Faint lemon, some white grape, and lager skunkiness. Meh. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
750ml bottle from Wilkes and Lynn. Gold pour with a bright white and soapy stick.  Aroma is farmhouse funk, lemon and hay.  Tastes are apricot, wheat, sugar, raisins. Fair enough.
UPDATED: NOV 26, 2012 Although its a workmans style this is a tremendous beer. The cadillac of the farmhouse if that makes any sense.

Bottle. Clear golden yellow with a thick white head. Spicy aroma with notes of strawberry, grass, hay, yeast, coriander, caramel. Taste is lightly sweet with notes of hay, lemon, earthy spices, horse staple, rye bread, yeast. Light dry bitterness and spicy finish. Well balanced.

Tap. Fluffy slightly tan head, on a mostly clear amber. Very nuanced light and pleasant fruit aromas, some sligt fruity yeast and eath. Flavor is less than impressive, turns fruit sweet with sweet hay as well, red apple meat, and too sweet. Medium to lighter body.

Appearance  was hazy caramel gold with diminishing creamy  off white 1 finger head, spotty lace. Aromas are sweet spicey floral farmhouse yeasts, then hints of citrus fruits, no alcohol present. Taste was sweet wheat, pale, 2-row malts, touch of caramel and honey. Hops play mild spicey lemon, orange, tangerine role with smooth funky yeasts. Palate was smooth soft CO2 with meduim body, then spicey funky lasting beautiful finish. A wonderful mix of styles... C&C 750 mL bottle from the Bound Brook, NJ Buy Rite. Pours a hazy orange color with a large creamy white head. Decent head retention. Aroma of spicy, herbal hops, orange, banana and pale malts. The taste is spicy, herbal hops, coriander and other spices, toasted malts, banana, pale malts. Medium bodied with lingering spice. Refreshing. Nice beer.

Draft at the Khyber. Orange gold pour with a large fizzy head that initially hid much of the aroma. Surprised, but delighted, to find a complex dry spicy floral balanced with a gentle brown sugar caramel sweetness. Easy to drink but try not to gulp it down because of both the well hidden high ABV and the complex flavors that you would miss otherwise. Orange. Clove. Cinnamon. Pinecones. Lavender. All with a wafting hint of caramel in the nose. Tastes dry but, once it warms, smells sweet. Thought definitely went into this one. Take some time to appreciate it.
Bomber poured into glass. Pretty stoked to finally try this one. I found this one to be a mix between a sour and saison. Slightly tart with floral hints. Very good carbonation and very well balanced.

Pours a light orange-ish amber with medium, thick white head. Earthy aroma with dough, hay, grass, yeast, a bit of basement. Taste is very saison like, but with a distinct, almost peppery finish. Medium carbonation, and quite full bodied. This is the first bière de garde Ive tried and I have to say I quite like it, like a saison on steroids.

Bottle 75 cl. Pours hazy amber in color with a white head. Grassy hops with floral notes and some bready malt in aroma.  Grassy hops in flavour as well along with something sweet like honey, hay also.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden/amber. Aroma and taste are yeast, fruits, malt, notes of caramel and hops.

Pretty close to a perfect beer for me   hazy yellow pour nice frothy white head   . Aroma of bread, lemon, grass.  Flavor mirrors   aroma  exceptional taste   amazing   palate feel is perfect   hard to top whats going on here
Hazy yelloy colour with nice big white fluffy head. Aroma is grassy, spicy with weast, Some sweet malts in there aswell. Taste is refreshing, malts, grass, a spicy sweetness. Good biere de garde!

Purchased 750 ML bottle at BevMo in Redding, CA. APPEARANCE / THE POUR: Medium light golden color, with 2-finger rocky head, excellent Brussels lace. AROMA / BOUQUET: Very similar to a Saison- it has that fresh grass, fresh sourdough bread smell, yeasty, granny smith green apples. Has a bit of the brett funk smell to it. TASTE: Nice hoppy / sour balance- great astringent cidery character to it. Fresh herbs, I dont get the slight sweetness that some people say that is in this beer... it tastes like a good example of the French Biere De Garde style. MOUTHFEEL / PALATE: Great fizziness, carbonation that hits the nose while swallowing. Great aftertaste, hop balance / sourness that hits the entire mouth. OVERALL: This beer exceeded my expectations... I will buy this again! Blessings and honor to this one!!
Pours hazy yellow with high head. Aroma is malts, grass, yeasty fruits. Flavor is malts and hops with a hint of sweet candy.

Pours a hazy honey color with a medium white head.  Aroma has a hint of apple and some straw and mild grass...fruity/yeasty.  Flavor follows suit but intensifies...particularly yeasty with some spice and grassiness.  Mouthfeel is full and silky with a dry bitter/grassy/spicy finish.
On Tap, hazy golden orange with a yeast and some funk.  Taste  is similar with some citrus and bitterness.  Good, but not great.

Somehow I never had this beer....time to rate it. Pours out a moderate golden color with a large off white head. Aroma is lemon zest, spice, hay and light tartness. Taste is some nice spice notes, lemon, light tartness, pepper, earth, bread and light funk. Nice and pretty easy drinking.
This is a lighter and refreshingly crisp beer from lost abbey. Has a sweeter taste but not too sweet. I like it

750ml bottle poured into a Bruery tulip glass. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a quarter inch head and a little bit of lacing. Aroma and taste is yeast, biscuit, dry farmhouse funk. Refeshing and pallet cleansing. Nice.

Bottle shared by durwoodx. Thanks Darrell!

Avant Garde appears a hazy, yellow straw color. There is a half inch of head that leaves a bit of lacing. The aroma is pleasant, with a mild funkiness. Golden with a small white head. Fruity and flowery tones. Malt, fruit and hops. Medium body with a nice, balanced finish.
Tap at CBC. Pours golden/yellow with medium head. Aroma is citrus, orange, pine and soma yeast. Taste is like aroma with some pepper and spices. Refreshing and nice balance.
Tap at CBC. Cloudy golden colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops and fruit.

CBC 2012. Pours clear golden amber with a small off white head leaving nice lace. Aroma is piny citric fruity hoppy malty. Flavor much like aroma with a good sustaining bitterness. Finishes bitter fruity and sweet.

Bottle at Patricks. Aroma is dust, fruit, malt, caramel, hop. Flavour is dust, fruit, malt, hop, peaches, orange , pine. Balanced nice beer.

text: Bottle from Vinmonopolet in Valkendorfsgate, Bergen. Pours a clear dark-hued orange body, crowned by a majestic, pillowy off-white head. Nose is Belgian ale yeast, dried apricots, floral honey tones and hints of molasses. Taste is dry Belgian yeast notes, bitter grassy hops, hints of molasses, honey and alcohol. Long, near-resinous bitter aftertaste. Much drier and more yeast-dominated than expected, and the 7 % ABV certainly comes through in this rather crisp and bitter creation. Its like a saison without the saison yeast tones, in a way, and rather different from the other Biere de Gardes Ive tried. Not quite my style of beer; I like more body and less dryness. Still, this is another example of the brewing  skills of Lost Abbey for sure.

750ml bottle from Luckyhank, thanks Brendan! Pours a cloudy, golden-orange colored body with a finger-width, frothy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is floral and perfume-like with a good amount of fruits and spices. Apples, pears, cherries, a touch of citrus, sweeter bready malts, clove, yeast, and caramel. Very bright, pleasant aroma. Flavor is pretty spicy with a light-medium bready malt balance. Lots of clove, yeast, a bit peppery, and some herbal hops. More apples, pears, cherries, and floral/perfume-like fruits with a touch of citrus. Some caramel comes in along with an earthy, herbal hopping before this finishes dry and spicy with a nice fruitiness and balancing bready malt. Light hop bitterness before leaving a fairly lengthy aftertaste. Medium, smooth body and creamy, somewhat high carbonation. Overall, a very enjoyable Bière de Garde. On the sweeter side, but not overly bready and there is a nice spiciness throughout to balance. Solid fruitiness and pleasant body as well. Good one.

bottle pours a clear golden orange, with fluffy white head.  Nose has some yeast to it and a very soft fruity aspect, perhaps pear, with some vanilla.  Medium bodied, extra smooth, with a soft  bitterness on the finish.  Flavor of bread, apple, softly bitter herbs.  Overall very drinkable, soft and refreshing, although not incredibly big in flavor or complexity.  Worth a try for sure.

Bottle shared by Darrell at a recent tasting. Served in a snifter.

Pours a yellow-orange color with a white head and a moderate amount of lacing on the way down. The nose brings forward quite a bit of grain and bread with some mild yeast presence and a touch of a farmhouse character. The taste is mostly just a bit of grainy malt without too much else. The finish is oddly dry and a bit too bitter. Not terribly drinkable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-31-2011

Bright, glowing light orange color with a bright white, bubbly head.  	Light, earthy sweet and creamy (if it could be an aroma).  Flavor is yeasty, but sweet and not nauseating.  Clean and really enjoyable.  Girls will love this.  And being a guy, well, even I like it.  Looking for a clean, light-bodied, but well-flavored beer?  You got it here!

Had at The Monks private tasting. Clear golden pour with a firm white head sitting on top. The head stays on and on. Grass is present on the aroma. Some honey, apple and yeast also come into play. Pine and citrus are at the forefront of the taste, seems to finish with apple, honey, yeast and bread/biscuit. Not bad but nothing wows me

750 ml bottle poured into a snifter. Cloudy orange-kissed golden pour, with a wispy white head that retained well and left the occasional thin ring of lacing. Aroma is fresh cut grass, lemons, orange rind, and bread. Flavor is mildly tart, with a light funk youd expect from a saison. Middle of the taste is mainly grassy hops, straw, and a tinge of orange and lemon zest.  Finish is somewhat dry, with a lasting pleasant bitterness. Palate is oily and thoroughly carbonated. My first beer in the "biere de garde" style, so Im not sure how typical this one is. I found it to be light and refreshing, but the flavor seemed rather mild for something tipping the scales at 7%.
75cl, American brew, from Brouwerij de Molen Bodegraven, complex brew, fruity and spicy, yet balanced, cloudy, rocky head, good brew, yet expensive!

750ml from Tennesseje420: Pours a cloudy peach or orange color with a sustained white head. Aroma is faint when it is still cold, but becomes intensley fruity as it warms up. While, the beer is plenty good, to me it tasted mostly like a Belgian ale and not a particuarly outstanding one at that. However, there is some bread in there and yeast is present, but not in as funky a way as I would have liked. Very fruity and a little bit on the sweet side. Very drinkable and i would be able to session it if it were not mailed to me from Colorado. A good beer, but a little underwhelming.

Bomber poured into a snifter.  Pours a hazy orange with a white head with good retention.  Aromas of yeast and some fruit.  Taste is clean and crisp with definite yeast characteristics.  Body is light to medium.  I havent had many of this type of beer but I did certainly enjoy this.  By the way does anyone else have trouble getting the damn cork of the Lost Abbey bombers?

It pours a hazy gold with a decent white head, ok lace. 

It has a light aroma of hops and citrus not very strong.

The tatse is good and smooth very easily drinkable. Not your traditional farm house, much better to drink.

Hazy copper coloured body with a thick dense tan head. Aroma of hay, grass, yeast, wheat, coriander seed, corn and a touch of curacao. Medium-bodied; Assertive yeast and wheat flavours with a little grass and coriander seed noticeable. Aftertaste is a bit more complex with some perfume, corn, alcohol, fruit sugars and a bit of hay. Overall, a decent beer - not as good as I expected, but compared to most Biere De Gardes, this is better than the middle. I sampled this 75 cL bottle purchased earlier in the day from BevMo in Danville, California, sampled here in Danville, California on 19-March-2011.

Bottle, Pours a clear golden color with a thin white head. Flowery aroma. Some malt and hops. A hint of alcohol in the aroma. Sweet taste with a hint of tartness. Pretty awesome taste. Mix of citrus, Hoppiness with some malt. Dry finish. Hint of alcohol as well.

750ml corked and caged bottle.

Pours a brownish orange color with a big fluffy white head. It has some lacing.

Smells like saison-light, it has some good farmhouse style ale scents such as a clean bready grain profile, yeast twang, slight spiciness, and some fruitiness but it isnt as intense as Belgian examples, Im not sure why though. 

The taste is mellow with alot of yeast character, some caramel, and fruitiness, ending with a spicy bitterness. There is a very acute spice character. It s pleasant.

Overall it is good but not great, I enjoy the Belgian produced ones a bit better.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-11-2010 00:31:17
somewhat roasted for what I was expecting but good. Medium sweetness - yeasty and slightly fruity, clean finish and good balance.
pours a bice golden color with a slim head and little lacing. Smells of bread, sweet malts, fruity spice. Taste is a malty fruit and light hops. Smooth finish.

750 ml bottle. Pored into a snifter, Hazy yellow cant see through. Nice big bubbly, white head.  Nose of citrus and light Belgian yeast notes. Taste mirrors the aroma.  Light bodied with a soft sour note in the finish leaving you wanting more. Easy drinker; better as it warms. Never would guess this is 7 % ABV. I dont taste any alcohol. I would have again.

750 ml bottle. Pored into a snifter, Hazy yellow cant see through. Nice big bubbly, white head.  Nose of citrus and light Belgian yeast notes. Taste mirrors the aroma.  Light bodied with a soft sour note in the finish leaving you wanting more. Easy drinker; better as it warms.Very low carbonation Never would guess this is 7 % ABV. I dont taste any alcohol. I would have again.

bottle.  clear golden/orange with a lively appearance, fast bubbles and a large, foamy, white head.  aroma is floral and herbal.  very clean scent with hops dominant.  palate is dry and quite light.  flavor has lots of bitterness.  hops and apple skins in flavor with light honey and herbal notes.
malty, yeasty/bread.  A bit flat and watery.  Is it possible to "not get" an entire brewery?  Because thats how I feel about Lost abbey.
Bottle a orange yellow colored beer with a white head aroma malts spices mint fruits and hops taste malts fruit spices some caramel and hops

Bottle; pour is a clear medium copper with a frothy white head that dissipates fairly quickly to the rim. Medium carbonation - caramel and barnyard aromas on the nose, caramel malts, barnyard funkiness, sour grapes, spicy pepper, lemon rind -

Courtesy of Pailhead. Clear golden/amber with no head. Clean malt up front, light fruit esters, not much there, have to dig. Light metallic background. Flavor much the same, sweet malt up front, fades rather quick, light fruit. Really underwhelmed for LA.

Thx paco. Nice gold hazy color with a medium sized fizzy white cap. Strawberries and mild pepper, champagne, honey, bread, tropical fruits, grapes.... This is kind of like a poor mans Sauvignon blanc. Tasty stuff - tart, pepper, wheat softness, mild citrus, bread, tangerine. A bit of a slick mouth feel. Hints of alcohol without the burn. Light fruity finish with a touch a bitterness that adds to the drying quality.

Purchased at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago, IL; enjoyed on NYE at a friends house party.  Appearance something like an amber ale with abundant frothy white head.  Aroma of bread and lemon pledge.  Taste features tons of spices, interesting, creamier as it settles.  Didnt really impress me.
pours hazy gold with a thin white head. Nice light, sweet fruit aroma. Flavor is much the same with a little barnyard character. Mouthfeel is light and crisp. Very drinkable

A: Snifter. Pours a cloudy orange/yellow with a pure white head with a fair retention rate and a decent amount of lacing.

S: Wild strawberries are all over this one, with some honey-like sweet malts. Slight sour tones.

T: Tons of flavor for a biere de garde. Complex malts with a smooth finish of light honey and light wild strawberries.

M: A little high on the carbonation level but it is pleasant. This is an extremely smooth beer.

D: Definitely a bottle to share with good company. This could be the best Biere de Garde I have had yet. Like the saying goes, "Port doesnt fall short

Aroma of bread, white grapes, spices and slight apricot.  Taste is similar with a touch of alcohol warmth and a light hop bitterness that lingers for a little while.  Nice and dry to let all of those flavors continue to pop off the tongue after the sip, including a nice little barnyard flavor.  Would be an awesome beer with a sweeter cheese like an apricot stilton.

Bottle at Brickskeller, shared with Greg and his gang, and Collin and his group.  Hazy golden, medium off white head.  Aroma of straw and white pepper.  Taste is very much like a saison, more full body, maybe some light spice.  Nice.
Cloudy appearance upon pour.  Bread smelling malts catch me right away with a slight sweetness to the nose.  The finish doesnt linger long, but the slightly sweet taste hit the spot.

Bottle shared by nuplastikk...thanks Greg! - Clear amber with a small foamy white head. Light and grainy, but with a sharp alcohol note that overpowers. Light and grainy, with a touch of lemon, but a real hot alcohol finish. Light and well carbonated, but just too sharp in nose and flavor.
Bottle. Pours cloudy orange. Nose and taste of lemongrass, Belgian yeast, fresh apple, peel and spice. Lots of yeast and basement aromas in the nose.

Bottle shared with JerC (old rate). Golden brown, ruby with a small head. Aromas are sweet, malty, herbal and spicy with alcohol. Flavours are sweet caramel and toffee malts with yeast. Fruity with ripe pear and raisins. Earthy with light pine hops on the finish. Nice.

medium brown with large white head.  bready nose with some esters.  moderate to high carbonation for the style.  low bitterness before some medium sweetness and esters with significant residual sweetness.  a solid version of style

Enjoyed from a 750ml bottle in a chalice.  The beer pours a light to medium amber color, with a dense and moderately large white head.  The nose shows continental character malt, along with a more restrained Franco-Belgian ester profile.  The palate is malty, reflecting the styles original intent as a warmer meant to be saved.  Hops come through to a measured extent, but reflect the restrained tones of European varietals.  The finish is lightly malty and lightly estery.  Carbonation seems calibrated beautifully.  Overall, an enjoyable example of a style rarely done spectacularly well.

Dark yellow colored with hazy appearance. Little yellow head. Fruity aroma with peach and yeast, slight spices also here. Medium bodied. Flavor is similar with peach and spicy note, some cacao-chocolaty note also. Aftertaste lasts with lemon and same toffee.

Bottled.
Fruit - peaches, ripe apples. Very subtle. Some ciderlike sourness. A little barn yard. Light malty body, spicy finish.

750 ml bottle from the Duck Blind in Santa Monica. Pours a cloudy ochre with tall foamy head and nice lace. Aroma has yeasty notes, citrus and slight floral. Flavor has yeasty bread, floral and vegetal notes with slight banana and dried fruit. Slight bitter in the aftertaste. Very nice beer.

Nice and tasty.  Pours a light amber with a small head. The aroma is earthy with a hint of sourness. The taste is 
similar with an earthy malty start and a sour end. Finish is light and crisp.

on draft at monks cafe in philly. Pours a hazy golden orang with small ring of offwhite head.  Spicy dry hop.  Kinda orvaly? Big carbonation, but soft on the palate. Sweet on the finish. Well done for what it is, but not really my cup of tea.

On draft at Iron Abbey. Pours a hazy citrus with a white head. I may have gotten a bad batch of this but to me it smelled very doughy and yeasty. Taste was full, biscuity, and clean finishing. Some floral tones come through, but very slightly. Not what i was expecting.
Pours a light yellow with a large white head. The aroma is fruityspicy and yeasty. The flavor is has peach, white pepper, chlorine, and grass. Ok, not great.

Bottle. Thanks to paco! I knew a guy in Junior High named Paco, everyone called him Taco. His mom was really fat, and lived in the scariest housing project in town:  Rideau Court. She was the first person who showed me a dildo, it was super-80s, and crusty. Taco was a strange guy. Pours clear orange, medium white head, epic lacing. Nose is fresh malty, wort/boiling wort aroma, with light orange zest, some spice, very soft and subtle. Flavours run to yeast, citrus, very Belgium, but very light. Tasty, but missing something.

Pours hazy orange with a very thin head. Smells great, yeast notes, vanilla, slighltly vegital. Nice flavour. bitter with a slight note of bannana and bread. this is a nice beer smells amazing but very thin in flavour and palate. it is very drinkable and well balanced but does not stand out.
Bottle. Clear gold/amber pour with a medium white head. Malty and creamy nose with a bit of hop and some yeast. Malty flavor with some creaminess and citrusy hops before a yeast finish.
Bottle at Monks.  Execellent beer for the style, has to be one of the best Bier de Gardes Ive sampled.  Doughy, spices, mossy, creamy.

750ml bottle thanks to aplusbreaks.  Pours a deep hazy orange with a thick 3 finger white frothy head which settles to a solid 1/4" throughout.  Pleasant, but subtle notes of apple, spice, dark fruits and hops through the nose.  Medium body with more apple notes, lighter spices, an earthy bitterness and a very soft palate.  Bitter dry finish with some citrus.  Overall a very drinkable and enjoyable Biere de Garde, but I would like something more dynamic... and funky.

Had at eulogy. Pour is a hazy Irans with a thin lasting head. Laces. Aroma is sweet hops and banaana. Flavor is a nice banana and b
Earthy breads. Nice lasting flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2010 Sample from a bottle at the Day Before Labor Day party. Pours a cloudy golden-orange color with a medium thin off-white head that recedes steadily. Stringy lacing. Aroma of peaches, bready malt and yeast. Medium body with flavors of sweet fruit, yeast, toasted bread and spice. The finish is fruity with a mild spice aftertaste. Decent overall.

There is a nice sweet and funky aroma with some orange zest. The color is clear and dark yellow with a small white head. The typical light flavor of a.biere de garde which provides a bit of funk and a bit of bitterness on a light -bodies beer.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Bottle at The Waterfront Bar and Grill in San Diego. Pours a golden color with good head that sticks to the sides of the glass. Mild scents in the nose - malty, sugars. Taste is a good ale - no added spices or overwhelming malts, just nice and easy. Warm aftertaste in the exhale.

Pours a clear orange-yellow color with a tall white head.  Aroma of bread, spice, and fruit.  Flavor of citrus fruit, spice, and bread.  Good for one session, not one you want a case of to drink daily.
Had this one at the UDRBM, 31-07-2010. Orange colored brew. Fruity aroma. Flavor has fruits, yeast, apricot.

750 ml bottle from Total Wine in Tustin purchased almost a year ago ($6.99).  Pours a dark orange-amber with one finger of off-white head.  Aroma is vaguely fruity, some caramel, spice, and a light hint of acidic sourness.  Flavor of tart apples, little bit of caramel, and some spice toward the end.  Somewhat dry finish.  Not overly impressed.  (499, 361)

Hazy pale golden pour ... light white head ... aroma of bready and sweet malt some faint belgian yeast .... taste of bready malts, sweet and tart fruits, honey and lightly herbal with a spicy floral hop finish ..... like a saison just more bready malts and more tartness ... a sipper and not bad

750 mL bottle, corked and caged.

A: Pours a reddish orange with a light white head.
S: Spices and a bit of fruit are prevalent.
T: Spicy like a saison, with some fruit on the finish, perhaps it is apple.
M: Medium bodied and well carbonated.
D: Somewhere between a session beer and a sipper. A whole bottle wouldnt be far-fetched.

Bottle @ meeting. Brownish clear amber, medium off white head. Aroma of faint fruit, faint hops, seems watery.
Flavour is fruity, (poperingse) hops, mild and easy drinker.
Nice and simple beer.
Pours cloudy orange with white head.  Aroma of caramel, dough and pear.  Taste is sweet, with a light crisp mouthfeel.
66cl Bottle at UDRBM. Clear golden orange colour, white head. Aroma is flowery, fruity, malty. Flavour is sweet, honey, fruity, light estery, malty finish with some alcohol. Medium bodied.
A nice beer, fairly flat but fitting to the beer. Lots of cereal grain and belgian sugar.

followed all the instructions.  1.  sit on porch.  2.   Fresh baked loaf of break.   3.  drink beer.   It was fine, just not what i was expecting.   Had a tripel-esque malt and candied sugar backing.   some bready cereal.  medium bodied doughy tripel.   I think i was in the mood for a saison, and grabbed a beer de garde.  so maybe im the real idiot here.   okay, not great beer.

Medium amber hue color. Sweet yeasty aroma somewhat floral, so far a good start.  Some slight pepper notes on the back of the palate.  Breadlike,  dry then creamy mouthfeel.   Slightly acidic, some lemon notes. Very quaffable. For the price and a cork, needs to be scaled in the high 4s.

Bottle at Dutch RB Meeting. Clear orange pour, thin white head. Aroma of fruity hops, sugary malts, some spices. Flavor is spicy malty sweet with some faint hops and typical Belgian yeast. Creamy texture and lively carbonation. Nice biere de Garde.
On tap at Varga.  Pours an amber orange color with a big white foam head.  Starts off sweet.  Gentle bitters kick in with some farmhouse funk.  Dry funk finish.

Yellow-gold pour with a small white head.  The aroma is sweet honey, light citrus, apple and some slight lactobaciliius.  The flavor has a nice even tartness, a little toffee on the finish, a hint of buttery diacetyl, slight nuttiness, and some more lightly sour fruit.  Dry, medium body with lots of carbonation.

750 ml bottle. Almost clear golden with a decent off-white head that fades. Aroma is relatively mild, spicy, some caramel and alcohol. Flavor is sweet, light malty, caramel, fruity and a bit perfumed spicy. Not particular complex really, but harmonic and pleasant. A Bière de Garde going in the direction of a trippel.
Amber  and orange in color. Smells very strong of oranges. A little bit creamy. A very good tasting beer.
From a 24 oz bottle,Fizzy,thick head,Amber,Orange,Cereal,creamy,bread,thin body,slick text.
Not bad. Colored just like apple juice with very little head. The taste is winey without being overpowering. Good malt with some yeast flavor. Not much else to say.

Pours a golden brown with a large off white head.  Aroma is pleasant, yeast and bready notes, some sour notes.  Body is somewhat light, carbonation is good.  Long finish, ends with a somewhat sour hoppy note.  Not bad, a little boring though.

750 ml bottle via trade with fidelis83- thanks again, Jeremiah!  Pours a hazy orange-plum-amber color with a finger-thick off-white head with a film that sticks on the beer for a long time.  Aroma of grapes, apples, honey, biscuity malts, cherries, fruitcake, fresh baked bread, and spices.  Flavor of apples, grapes, bready malts, spices, caramel, overripe pit fruits, honey, biscuits, and wet leaves.  Dry finish and apples in the aftertaste.  Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a bready mouthfeel.  Really good biere de garde, maybe the best Ive had so far.
Pours a cloudy honey color with a thin white head.  Malt, bread, spicy fruit, and barnyard yeast aromas and flavors.  Crisp clean taste with high carbonation.  Very refreshing.

Medium white head. Hazy deep yellow body. Herbal mineraly fruity aroma with bubblegum and eucalyptus notes. Vaguely artificial. Dry-sweetish herbal floral taste with strawy mineraly alcohol notes. Mild mouthfeel. Light body. Dry mineraly floral fruity aftertaste with eucalyptus and alcohol notes. Nice, but not major. (0.75 bottle, Håndverkerstuene, Oslo.)

Bottle from Philadelphia craft beer outlet.  Nice cloudy gold/ bronze pour. Looks like honey. Nice bread and spice aroma with notes of fruit. Finish is dry with mild yeat and fruit. However, it is belnded really nice. I liked it alot.

Clear golden body with a tanned head and fair lacing. Wonderful floral and malty caramel aroma. Taste is alcoholic and sweet and bitter spicy as with Belgian ale yeast. Medium bodied. Dry. Very pleasant.

Shared bottle @ Cardinal, Stavanger. Pours unclear orange with a small white head. Aroma of malts, some spice.Taste is dark malts, spicy, some dried fruits, raisins.Nice beer

Sampled from bottle@Håndverkerstuene, Oslo. Firm near-white head. Body is gold colored with an orange hue. Slight ashy malt aroma paired with a fine spice scent and a whiff of orange marmelade and marzipan. Taste is medium malty and fairly dry.  Also a fresh, spicy fruitiness. Mildly hopped. Thanks! Poured into my Chimay chalice.

A-Body is a translucent dark gold hue. Pours with a 1 finger or so creamy white head that fades quickly to a thin collar. Some traces of lacing is left behind in the glass. Cloudiness is uniform and so thick that the body is nearly opaque.

S-Nose is very good. A balance of white grapes, raisins, and maybe pear upfront with a big accent of spiciness. A big dose of sweet, bready yeast provides a great background.

T-The taste upfront is mild and offers some mellow fruitiness accented by minimal spiciness. The sweet bready yeast so prominent can only be found when the brew is swished around over the palate a bit. The main character in the finish (and in the flavor overall) is a big bad floral hop bitterness. Below this bitterness is a nice balance of floral hop flavor, breadiness and a hint of spice. What lingers, surprisingly is a slight phenolic bitterness and alcohol warmth and nothing else.

M-Medium to high carbonation and medium weight body composed of sweet bready yeast and powdery spiciness.

D-This is a decent to pretty good beer. Not the best LA beer or Biere de Garde I have had but still a very interesting brew. I wish the taste were as good as the smell-but it falls short for me. Definitely worth a try.

Serving type: bottle
